caption: Exploring the many covered passages of this amazing city, is a fun day out, we love the quirkiness of the many shops, we are always amazed how punters are never bothered being crammed in tiny tables, its like a obstacle course at times getting around them. all part of the experience.
It's a nice place to be if you want to have lunch or shop for christmas and stuff. The passage is beautiful nowadays due to Christmas decorations.

One of several 19th century covered passages  or arcades. This one has a good variety of shops, including a lovely one for people seeking crosshatch & needlework projects. A lot of the windows are beautifully presented- currently mainly with Christmas themes.
Cute old passages with cafes restaurants and old book shops!
Great restaurant and bar options. Nice art and shopping.

A lovely parisian covered passage ! It's one of the most charming among the secret passages hidden in Paris. Built in 1847, is the continuation of two other well known arcades: Les Panoramas* and Jouffroy*. You will find shops with old books, postcards, antiques dealers, collectors' cameras and a Belle √âpoque atmosphere. Open: Monday to Friday 7.30am to 9pm, Saturday & Sunday 7.30am to 8.30pm. 6, rue de la Grange-Bateli√®re & 31 bis, rue du Faubourg Montmartre; arr. 9, Paris. M√©tros: Richelieu Drouot & Grands Boulevards.
Quite a historical place. When walking through, it feels as if you've gone back in time. Nice little gift shops and restaurants. Beautiful üòä ‚Ä¶
Cute little shopping arcade with boutique stores. If you are looking for old books, maps, art etc this is where you'll find them

From the gardens of the Palais Royal starts the Gallerie Vivienne, then the Passage des Panoramas, then the Passage Jouffroy and finally the Passage Verdeau. The Passage Verdeau, inaugurated in 1846, is essentially an extension of the Passage des Panoramas and the Passage Jouffroy. The truth is that this Passage was always considered subordinate to the two previous ones and that was the reason why it remained empty and neglected for many years. Nevertheless, its neoclassical design and high, glass ceiling have made it a favorite over the years among Parisians who visit it for a quick lunch on their break from work.
If you want to breathe and absorb Paris with all your senses... just go there through the passage.
It has some unique boutique shops, just mind that most of them don't open on Sunday

It's beauty is fading. More locals are empty .  Love walking the passages, every one visiting Paris should-must walk them as a jewel of true local commerce and curiosities you can find in a middle of a complete accommodated touristic city that is no longer a true experience of french culture.

We stumbled across this place later in the evening, after dinner. The two guys working the bar were very friendly even though we didn't speak French and the bartender did not speak English, they still made us feel very welcome, and even after their closing time didn't rush us and insisted we stick around to finish our bottle of wine. Highly recommend for a relaxed atmosphere and a great staff
Just passing by accidentally, the place is awesome with lights along the corridor
Couple verre doze. Carafe de l'eau. It's stunning and magical. My daughter had fun reading all the signs of the shops she can't go in (6 year old touching antiques yeah great idea!)

A lovely place to stroll, window shop and have a coffee. With shops arranged tastefully and displays that compete with small museums...wouldn‚Äôt it be cool if all malls were like this.  Find tintin display.  Gaze at fine art etchings. Look At the floors. Look at the ceiling. Look all around. Its lovely.  Stop at the ‚Äúbook store‚Äù outside the front gate and buy a button, postcard or even a book and you will be contributing to a French institution.  Get a pastry in the pastry shop inside and become part of the institution of French life.  It‚Äôs lovely.

A delightful arcade full of fantastical trash and treasure boutiques, antique shops and cafes. You'll find some real gems walking through here.  It's easy to walk straight passed and not notice, so keep your eyes on your map.
Very nice place to visit. Old shops mix with modern restaurants. Great little detour for a walk and a bit of shopping.
The ambience is super cute but the Ramen unfortunately isn't very rich in flavor (pretty boring taste :/)
Paris's hidden passages remain to be discovered by you!
cool street, loads of interesting shops. there are a couple of places I've since added to my must eat list.
Love it so many little shops
Cool walk.  I didn't stop at any of the shops along it but I did walk through it several times on my way elsewhere.
Very nice you can find anything there from old arts to books and great restaurants and coffee shop as well clothes and toys...
This is one of the must see in Paris area. Very artistic . You can find several paintings and antiques in in .
What a gem! Fun stores, trust me!
Must walk through the passages, can buy something interesting when visite Paris
So much to do and to see around here I could spend hours and not see the time fly by
Cool place! Find it and you will see!
Great vibe and friendly warm service from the staff. Food and drink reasonable priced and if a high standard
Nice passage
Such a cute Passage!with the best ramen place!
Nice small street. A bit difficult to find but many interesting things.
Very nice passage, lovely small arts shops.
Pretty passage with a lot of interesting small stores.
Lovely place to stroll and enjoy the atmosphere
Semi interesting overcrowded tourist spot.
One of the most impressive Passages of Paris
